{{chembox | verifiedrevid = 427512000 | Name = '''Lithium fluoride''' | ImageFile1 = LiF-crystal.jPeG | ImageSize1 = 120px | ImageName1 = Lithium fluoride boule | ImageFile2 = Lithium-fluoride-3D-ionic.png | ImageSize2 = 120px | ImageName2 = Lithium fluoride | IUPACName = Lithium fluoride | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | InChI = 1/FH.Li/h1H;/q;+1/p-1 | InChIKey = PQXKHYXIUOZZFA-REWHXWOFAG | SMILES = [Li+].[F-] | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/FH.Li/h1H;/q;+1/p-1 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = PQXKHYXIUOZZFA-UHFFFAOYSA-M | CASNo = 7789-24-4 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 23007 | PubChem = 224478 | EINECS = 232-152-0 | RTECS = OJ6125000 }} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = LiF | MolarMass = 25.939(2) g/mol | Appearance = white powder or transparent crystals,
[[hygroscopic]] | Density = 2.635 g/cm3 | Solubility = 0.127 g/100 mL (18 °C)
0.134 g/100 mL (25 °C) | SolubleOther = soluble in [[hydrofluoric acid|HF]]
insoluble in [[alcohol]] | MeltingPtC = 845 | BoilingPtC = 1676 | RefractIndex = 1.3915 | MagSus = −10.1·10−6 cm3/mol }} | Section3 = {{Chembox Structure | MolShape = Linear | CrystalStruct = Cubic | LattConst_a = 403.51 pm }} | Section4 = {{Chembox Thermochemistry | DeltaHf = -616 kJ/mol | DeltaHc = | Entropy = 1.376 J/(g K) | HeatCapacity = 1.604 J/(g K) }} | Section5 = {{Chembox Hazards | GHSPictograms = {{GHS skull and crossbones}} | GHSSignalWord = Danger | HPhrases = {{H-phrases|301|315|319|335}}https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/catalog/product/aldrich/449903?lang=en®ion=US | NFPA-H = 3 | NFPA-R = 0 | NFPA-F = 0 | RPhrases = | SPhrases = | LD50 = 143 mg/kg (oral, rat){{cite web |url=http://chem.sis.nlm.nih.gov/chemidplus/rn/7789-24-4 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812202636/http://chem.sis.nlm.nih.gov/chemidplus/rn/7789-24-4 |archivedate=2014-08-12 |df= }} }} | Section6 = {{Chembox Related | OtherAnions = [[Lithium chloride]]
[[Lithium bromide]]
[[Lithium iodide]]
[[Lithium astatide]] | OtherCations = [[Sodium fluoride]]
[[Potassium fluoride]]
[[Rubidium fluoride]]
[[Caesium fluoride]]
[[Francium fluoride]] }} }} '''Lithium fluoride''' is an [[inorganic compound]] with the [[chemical formula]] LiF. It is a colorless solid, that transitions to white with decreasing crystal size. Although odorless, lithium fluoride has a bitter-saline taste. Its structure is analogous to that of [[sodium chloride]], but it is much less soluble in water. It is mainly used as a component of [[molten salt]]s.J. Aigueperse, P. Mollard, D. Devilliers, M. Chemla, R. Faron, R. Romano, J. P. Cuer, "Fluorine Compounds, Inorganic" in Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2005. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a11_307}}. Formation of LiF from the elements releases one of the highest [[Energy Density|energy per mass of reactants]], second only to that of [[BeO]]. ==Manufacturing== LiF is prepared from [[lithium hydroxide]] or [[lithium carbonate]] with [[hydrogen fluoride]].S.L. Bellinger et al. "Improved High Efficiency Stacked Microstructured Neutron Detectors Backfilled with Nanoparticle 6LiF," IEEE Trans. Nucl. Sci., '''59''' (2012) 167-173 . ==Applications== ===In molten salts=== Fluorine is produced by the [[electrolysis]] of molten [[potassium bifluoride]]. This electrolysis proceeds more efficiently when the electrolyte contains a few percent of LiF, possibly because it facilitates formation of Li-C-F interface on the carbon [[electrode]]s. A useful molten salt, [[FLiNaK]], consists of a mixture of LiF, together with [[sodium fluoride]] and [[potassium fluoride]]. The primary coolant for the [[Molten-Salt Reactor Experiment]] was [[FLiBe]]; LiF-BeF2 (66-33 mol%). ===Optics=== Because of the large [[band gap]] for LiF, its crystals are [[transparency (optics)|transparent]] to short wavelength [[ultraviolet]] [[electromagnetic radiation|radiation]], more so than any other [[chemical substance|material]]. LiF is therefore used in specialized UV [[optics]],{{cite web | title= Crystran Ltd., a manufacturer of infrared and ultraviolet optics| url=http://www.crystran.co.uk/lithium-fluoride-lif.htm | accessdate = 2010-12-28}} (See also [[magnesium fluoride]]). Lithium fluoride is used also as a diffracting crystal in X-ray spectrometry. ===Radiation detectors=== It is also used as a means to record [[ionizing radiation]] exposure from [[gamma rays]], [[beta particles]], and [[neutrons]] (indirectly, using the [[Lithium-6|{{nuclide|lithium|6}}]] (n,alpha) [[nuclear reaction]]) in [[thermoluminescent dosimeter]]s. 6LiF nanopowder enriched to 96% has been used as the neutron reactive backfill material for microstructured semiconductor neutron detectors (MSND) D.S. McGregor, S.L. Bellinger, and J.K. Shultis, "Present Status of Microstructured Semiconductor Neutron Detectors, '''379''' (2013) 99-110.. ===Nuclear reactors=== Lithium fluoride (highly enriched in the common isotope lithium-7) forms the basic constituent of the preferred fluoride salt mixture used in [[Liquid Fluoride Reactor|liquid-fluoride nuclear reactors]]. Typically lithium fluoride is mixed with [[beryllium fluoride]] to form a base solvent ([[FLiBe]]), into which fluorides of uranium and thorium are introduced. Lithium fluoride is exceptionally chemically stable and LiF/BeF2 mixtures ([[FLiBe]]) have low melting points (360 C - 459 C) and the best neutronic properties of fluoride salt combinations appropriate for reactor use. [[Molten-Salt Reactor Experiment|MSRE]] used two different mixtures in the two cooling circuits. ===Cathode for PLED and OLEDs=== Lithium fluoride is widely used in [[PLED]] and [[OLED]] as a coupling layer to enhance electron injection. The thickness of LiF layer is usually around 1 nm. The dielectric constant (or relative permittivity) of LiF is 9.0 C. Andeen, J. Fontanella,D. Schuel, "Low-Frequency Dielectric Constant of LiF, NaF, NaC1, NaBr, KC1, and KBr by the Method of Substitution", Physical Review B, 2, 5068-5073 (1970) {{DOI|10.1103/PhysRevB.2.5068}}. ===Natural occurrence=== Naturally occurring lithium fluoride is known as the mineral griceite. It is extremely rare.Mindat {{cite web |url=http://www.mindat.org/min-1749.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307080246/http://www.mindat.org/min-1749.html |archivedate=2014-03-07 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Lithium compounds}} {{fluorine compounds}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Lithium compounds]] [[Category:Fluorides]] [[Category:Alkali metal fluorides]] [[Category:Optical materials]] [[Category:Crystals]] [[Category:Metal halides]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} Knowledge of the '''location of Earth''' has been shaped by 400 years of telescopic observations, and has expanded radically in the last century. Initially, Earth was believed to be the [[Geocentric model|center of the Universe]], which consisted only of those planets visible with the [[classical planet|naked eye]] and an outlying sphere of [[fixed stars]].{{cite book |first=Thomas S. |last=Kuhn |title=The Copernican Revolution |pages=5–20 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |date=1957 |isbn=978-0-674-17103-9}} After the acceptance of the [[heliocentric model]] in the 17th century, observations by [[William Herschel]] and others showed that the Sun lay within a vast, disc-shaped [[galaxy]] of stars.{{cite web|title=1781: William Herschel Reveals the Shape of our Galaxy|url=http://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1781|publisher=[[Carnegie Institution for Science]]|accessdate=19 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140326182039/http://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1781|archivedate=26 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} By the 20th century, observations of [[spiral nebula]]e revealed that our galaxy was one of billions in an [[expanding universe]],{{cite web|title=The Spiral Nebulae and the Great Debate|publisher=[[Eberly College of Science]]|url=https://www.e-education.psu.edu/astro801/content/l9_p2.html|accessdate=22 April 2015}}{{cite web|title=1929: Edwin Hubble Discovers the Universe is Expanding|publisher=Carnegie Institution for Science|url=https://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1929|accessdate=22 April 2015}} grouped into clusters and [[supercluster]]s. By the end of the 20th century, the [[large-scale structure of the cosmos|overall structure]] of the visible universe was becoming clearer, with superclusters forming into a vast web of [[galactic filament|filaments]] and [[Void (astronomy)|voids]].{{cite web|title=1989: Margaret Geller and John Huchra Map the Universe|publisher=[[Carnegie Institution for Science]]|url=https://cosmology.carnegiescience.edu/timeline/1989|accessdate=22 April 2015}} Superclusters, filaments and voids are the largest coherent structures in the Universe that we can observe.{{cite web|title=Structure of the Universe|author= Villanueva, John Carl |publisher=[[Universe Today]]|year=2009|url=http://www.universetoday.com/37360/structure-of-the-universe/|accessdate=22 April 2015}} At still larger scales (over 1000 [[megaparsec]]s{{efn|name=parsec|A parsec (pc) is the distance at which a star's [[parallax]] as viewed from Earth is equal to one [[second of arc]], equal to roughly 206,000 AU or 3.0857×1013 km. One [[megaparsec]] (Mpc) is equivalent to one million [[parsec]]s.}}) the Universe becomes homogeneous meaning that all its parts have on average the same density, composition and structure.{{cite book |title=The Extravagant Universe: Exploding Stars, Dark Energy and the Accelerating Cosmos |author=Kirshner, Robert P. |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qQ_mV2prqNYC&pg=PA71 |page=71 |isbn=978-0-691-05862-7 |date=2002 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]}} Since there is believed to be no "center" or "edge" of the Universe, there is no particular reference point with which to plot the overall location of the Earth in the universe.{{cite book |title=The Little Book of Time |author1=Mainzer, Klaus |author2=Eisinger, J. |isbn=978-0-387-95288-8 |date=2002 |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wX111YnexSUC&pg=PA55|page=55}} Because the [[observable universe]] is defined as that region of the Universe visible to terrestrial observers, Earth is, by definition, the center of Earth's observable universe.{{cite book|author1=Liddle, Andrew R. |author2=Lyth, David Hilary |title=Cosmological inflation and large-scale structure|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XmWauPZSovMC&pg=PA24|date= 2000|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-57598-0|pages=24–}} Reference can be made to the Earth's position with respect to specific structures, which exist at various scales. It is still undetermined whether the Universe is [[Infinity|infinite]]. There have been numerous hypotheses that our universe may be only one such example within a higher [[multiverse]]; however, no direct evidence of any sort of multiverse has ever been observed, and some have argued that the hypothesis is not [[falsifiable]].{{cite web|title=5 Reasons We May Live in a Multiverse |url=http://www.space.com/18811-multiple-universes-5-theories.html |author= Moskowitz, Clara|publisher=space.com|year=2012|accessdate=29 April 2015}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1080/00033790903047725| title = Contemporary History of Cosmology and the Controversy over the Multiverse| journal = Annals of Science| volume = 66| issue = 4| pages = 529–551| year = 2009| last1 = Kragh | first1 = H. }} [[File:Location of Earth (1x9-English Annot-small).png|thumb|200px|right|A diagram of our location in the [[observable universe]].]] {|class="wikitable" |- !Feature || Diameter || Notes || Sources |- |'''[[Earth]]''' || 12,756.2 km
(equatorial) || Measurement comprises just the solid part of the Earth; there is no agreed upper boundary for [[Earth's atmosphere]].
The [[geocorona]], a layer of UV-luminescent hydrogen atoms, lies at 100,000 km.
The [[Kármán line]], defined as the boundary of space [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale|for astronautics]], lies at 100 km. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|title=Selected Astronomical Constants, 2011|work=The Astronomical Almanac|url=http://asa.usno.navy.mil/SecK/2011/Astronomical_Constants_2011.txt|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826043456/http://asa.usno.navy.mil/SecK/2011/Astronomical_Constants_2011.txt|archivedate=26 August 2013|accessdate=25 February 2011}}[[World Geodetic System]] (''WGS-84''). [http://earth-info.nga.mil/GandG/wgs84/ Available online] from [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] Retrieved 27 April 2015.{{cite web|title=Exosphere – overview|publisher=University Corporation for Atmospheric Research|year=2011|url=http://scied.ucar.edu/shortcontent/exosphere-overview|accessdate=28 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.org/icare-records/100km-altitude-boundary-for-astronautics|title=The 100 km Boundary for Astronautics|author=S. Sanz Fernández de Córdoba|publisher=[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]|date=2004-06-24|accessdate=2014-05-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/618QHms8h?url=http://www.fai.org/astronautics/100km.asp|archivedate=22 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} |- |[[Orbit of the Moon]] ||768,210 km{{efn|name=axes|[[semi-major axis|Semi-major]] and [[semi-minor axis|semi-minor axes]].}} || The average diameter of the orbit of the Moon relative to the Earth. || style="text-align:center;" | [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/moonfact.html NASA Moon Factsheet] and [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Moon&Display=Facts NASA Solar System Exploration Moon Factsheet] ''[[NASA]]'' Retrieved on 17 November 2008 |- |[[Geospace]] ||6,363,000–12,663,000 km
(110–210 Earth radii) || The space dominated by [[Earth's magnetic field]] and its [[magnetotail]], shaped by the [[solar wind]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{citation | last1=Koskinen | first1=Hannu | date=2010 | title=Physics of Space Storms: From the Surface of the Sun to the Earth | series=Environmental Sciences Series | publisher=Springer | isbn=978-3-642-00310-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cO0nwfhXVjUC&pg=PA32}} |- |[[Earth's orbit]] ||299.2 million km{{efn|name=axes}}
2 [[Astronomical unit|AU]]{{efn|name=au|1 AU or [[astronomical unit]] is the distance between the Earth and the Sun, or 150 million km. Earth's orbital diameter is twice its orbital radius, or 2 AU.}}|| The average diameter of the orbit of the Earth relative to the Sun.
Encompasses the [[Sun]], [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] and [[Venus]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/earthfact.html |title=Earth Fact Sheet |publisher=[[NASA]] |access-date=17 November 2008}} and {{cite web |url=http://sse.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Earth&Display=Facts&System=Metric |website=Solar System Exploration |title=Earth: Facts & Figures |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827003435/http://sse.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Earth&Display=Facts&System=Metric |archive-date=27 August 2009 |publisher=[[NASA]] |access-date=17 November 2008}} |- |[[Inner Solar System]] || ~6.54 AU || Encompasses the Sun, the [[inner planets]] (Mercury, Venus, Earth, [[Mars]]) and the [[asteroid belt]].
Cited distance is the 2:1 [[orbital resonance|resonance]] with Jupiter, which marks the outer limit of the asteroid belt. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |author1=Petit, J.-M. |author2=Morbidelli, A. |author3=Chambers, J. | title=The Primordial Excitation and Clearing of the Asteroid Belt | journal=[[Icarus (journal)|Icarus]] | date=2001 | volume=153 | issue=2 | pages=338–347 | url=http://www.gps.caltech.edu/classes/ge133/reading/asteroids.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate=22 March 2007 | doi = 10.1006/icar.2001.6702 | bibcode=2001Icar..153..338P }}{{cite journal|title= Asteroids in the 2 : 1 resonance with Jupiter: dynamics and size distribution|author1=Roig, F. |author2=Nesvorný, D. |author3= Ferraz-Mello, S. |last-author-amp=yes |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=335|issue=2|pages=417–431|year=2002|bibcode = 2002MNRAS.335..417R |doi = 10.1046/j.1365-8711.2002.05635.x }}{{cite journal|title=Yarkovsky origin of the unstable asteroids in the 2/1 mean motionresonance with Jupiter| journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=359| issue=4|pages=1437–1455|year=2005|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08995.x|bibcode=2005MNRAS.359.1437B| last1=Brož| first1=M| last2=Vokrouhlický| first2=D| last3=Roig| first3=F| last4=Nesvorný| first4=D| last5=Bottke| first5=W. F| last6=Morbidelli| first6=A}} |- |[[Outer Solar System]] || 60.14 AU || Includes the [[outer planets]] ([[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], [[Uranus]], [[Neptune]]).
Cited distance is the orbital diameter of Neptune. || style="text-align:center;" | [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/neptunefact.html NASA Neptune factsheet] and [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Neptune&Display=Facts NASA Solar System Exploration Neptune Factsheet] ''NASA'' Retrieved on 17 November 2008 |- |[[Kuiper belt]] || ~96 AU || Belt of icy objects surrounding the [[outer Solar System]]. Encompasses the [[dwarf planet]]s [[Pluto]], [[Haumea (dwarf planet)|Haumea]] and [[Makemake (dwarf planet)|Makemake]].
Cited distance is the 2:1 [[orbital resonance|resonance]] with Neptune, generally regarded as the inner edge of the main Kuiper belt. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |title=Thermal Evolution and Differentiation of Edgeworth–Kuiper Belt Objects |journal=[[The Astronomical Journal]] |doi= 10.1086/320385 |volume=121 |issue= 5 |pages=2792–2799 |date=2001 |bibcode=2001AJ....121.2792D|last1=De Sanctis |first1=M. C |last2=Capria |first2=M. T |last3=Coradini |first3=A }} |- |[[Heliosphere]] || 160 AU|| Maximum extent of the [[solar wind]] and the [[interplanetary medium]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|title=Cassini's Big Sky: The View from the Center of Our Solar System |author=NASA/JPL |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/features.cfm?feature=2370&msource=F20091119&tr=y&auid=5615216 |date=2009 |accessdate=20 December 2009}}{{cite journal |date=2000 |author=Fahr, H. J. |author2=Kausch, T. |author3=Scherer, H. |title=A 5-fluid hydrodynamic approach to model the Solar System-interstellar medium interaction |journal=[[Astronomy & Astrophysics]] |volume=357 |pages=268 |url=http://aa.springer.de/papers/0357001/2300268.pdf |format=PDF |bibcode=2000A&A...357..268F }} See Figures 1 and 2. |- |[[Scattered disc]] || 195.3 AU|| Region of sparsely scattered icy objects surrounding the Kuiper belt. Encompasses the dwarf planet [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]].
Cited distance is derived by doubling the [[aphelion]] of Eris, the farthest known scattered disc object.
As of now, Eris's aphelion marks the farthest known point in the scattered disc. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |type=2008-10-04 last obs |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 136199 Eris (2003 UB313) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=Eris |accessdate=21 January 2009}} |- |[[Oort cloud]] || 100,000–200,000 AU
0.613–1.23 [[parsec|pc]]{{efn|name=parsec}} || Spherical shell of over a trillion (1012) [[comet]]s. Existence is currently hypothetical, but inferred from the orbits of [[long-period comet]]s. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite arXiv |title=Origin and dynamical evolution of comets and their reservoir |author=Morbidelli, Alessandro |eprint=astro-ph/0512256 |date=2005 }} |- |'''[[Solar System]]''' || 1.23 pc || The Sun and its [[planetary system]]. Cited diameter is that of the Sun's [[Hill sphere]]; the region of its gravitational influence. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite book|last=Littmann|first=Mark|title=Planets Beyond: Discovering the Outer Solar System|date=2004|pages=162–163|publisher=Courier Dover Publications|isbn=978-0-486-43602-9}} |- |[[Local Interstellar Cloud]] || 9.2 pc || [[Interstellar cloud]] of gas through which the Sun and a number of other stars are currently travelling. || style="text-align:center;" | Mark Anderson, "Don't stop till you get to the Fluff", ''[[New Scientist]]'' no. 2585, 6 January 2007, pp. 26–30 |- |[[Local Bubble]] || 2.82–250 pc || Cavity in the [[interstellar medium]] in which the Sun and a number of other stars are currently travelling.
Caused by a past [[supernova]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|title=Mapping the Countours of the Local Bubble|author=Seifr, D.M. |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics|volume=346|date=1999|pages=785–797|bibcode= 1999A&A...346..785S}}{{cite web|title=Evidence for Supernovas Near Earth|url=https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2014/26aug_localbubble/|author=Phillips, Tony |publisher=NASA|year=2014|accessdate=2015-04-30}} |- |[[Gould Belt]] || 1,000 pc || Ring of young stars through which the Sun is currently travelling.|| style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|title=Young isolated neutron stars from the Gould Belt |journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics| volume=406|issue=1|pages=111–117|date=2003|doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20030680|bibcode=2003A&A...406..111P|arxiv = astro-ph/0304141 |last1=Popov|first1=S. B|last2=Colpi|first2=M|last3=Prokhorov|first3=M. E|last4=Treves|first4=A|last5=Turolla|first5=R}} |- |[[Orion Arm]]|| 3000 pc
(length)||The [[spiral arm]] of the Milky Way Galaxy through which the Sun is currently travelling.
|| style="text-align:center;" | |- |[[Galactic year|Orbit of the Solar System]] || 17,200 pc|| The average diameter of the orbit of the Solar System relative to the [[Galactic Center]].
The Sun's orbital radius is roughly 8,600 parsecs, or slightly over half way to the galactic edge.
One orbital period of the Solar System lasts between 225 and 250 million years. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |first1=F. |last=Eisenhauer |first2=R. |last2=Schoedel |first3=R. |last3=Genzel |first4=T. |last4=Ott |first5=M. |last5=Tecza |first6= R. |last6=Abuter |first7=A. |last7=Eckart |first8=T. |last8=Alexander |title=A Geometric Determination of the Distance to the Galactic Center |journal=[[Astrophysical Journal]] |volume=597 |issue=2 |pages=L121–L124 |date=2003 |doi=10.1086/380188 |bibcode=2003ApJ...597L.121E |arxiv = astro-ph/0306220 }}{{cite web|url=http://hypertextbook.com/facts/2002/StacyLeong.shtml|work=The Physics Factbook|last=Leong|first=Stacy|date=2002|title=Period of the Sun's Orbit around the Galaxy (Cosmic Year)}} |- |'''[[Milky Way Galaxy]]''' || 30,000 pc || Our home [[galaxy]], composed of 200 billion to 400 billion stars and filled with the [[interstellar medium]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|publisher=NASA | last = Christian | first = Eric | last2 = Samar | first2 = Safi-Harb | title = How large is the Milky Way? | url=http://imagine.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/ask_astro/answers/980317b.html | accessdate = 28 November 2007 }}{{cite web |author1=Frommert, H. |author2=Kronberg, C. | date =25 August 2005 | url =http://messier.seds.org/more/mw.html | title =The Milky Way Galaxy | publisher =[[SEDS]] | accessdate = 9 May 2007 }} |- |[[Milky Way subgroup]] || 840,500 pc || The Milky Way and those satellite [[dwarf galaxies]] gravitationally bound to it.
Examples include the [[Sagittarius Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy|Sagittarius Dwarf]], the [[Ursa Minor Dwarf]] and the [[Canis Major Dwarf]].
Cited distance is the orbital diameter of the [[Leo T Dwarf]] galaxy, the most distant galaxy in the Milky Way subgroup. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|last=Irwin|first=V.|author2=Belokurov, V.|author3=Evans, N. W.|display-authors=etal|title=Discovery of an Unusual Dwarf Galaxy in the Outskirts of the Milky Way|date=2007|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=656|issue=1|pages=L13–L16|doi=10.1086/512183|bibcode=2007ApJ...656L..13I|arxiv=astro-ph/0701154 }} |- |[[Local Group]] ||3 [[megaparsec|Mpc]]{{efn|name=parsec}}|| [[Galaxy groups and clusters|Group]] of at least 54 galaxies of which the Milky Way is a part.
Dominated by [[Andromeda Galaxy|Andromeda]] (the largest), the Milky Way and [[Triangulum Galaxy|Triangulum]]; the remainder are [[dwarf galaxies]].|| style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|title=The Local Group of Galaxies|url=http://messier.seds.org/more/local.html|publisher=Students for the Exploration and Development of Space|work=University of Arizona|accessdate=2 October 2009}} |- |[[Local Sheet]] ||7 Mpc|| Group of galaxies including the Local Group moving at the same relative velocity towards the [[Virgo Cluster]] and away from the [[Local Void]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal | last1=Tully | first=R. Brent | last2=Shaya | first2=Edward J. | last3=Karachentsev | first3=Igor D. | last4=Courtois | first4=Hélène M. | last5=Kocevski | first5=Dale D. | last6=Rizzi | first6=Luca | last7=Peel | first7=Alan | title=Our Peculiar Motion Away from the Local Void | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | volume=676 | issue=1 | pages=184–205 |date=March 2008 | doi=10.1086/527428 | arxiv=0705.4139 | bibcode=2008ApJ...676..184T }}{{cite book | last1=Tully | first1=R. Brent | chapter=The Local Void is Really Empty | title=Dark Galaxies and Lost Baryons, Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union, IAU Symposium | journal=Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union | volume=244 | pages=146–151 |date=May 2008 | doi=10.1017/S1743921307013932 | bibcode=2008IAUS..244..146T | arxiv=0708.0864 }} |- |[[Virgo Supercluster]] || 30 Mpc || The [[supercluster]] of which the Local Group is a part.
It comprises roughly 100 [[galaxy groups and clusters]], centred on the [[Virgo Cluster]].
The Local Group is located on the outer edge of the Virgo Supercluster. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal|title=The Local Supercluster|author=Tully, R. Brent |journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=257|pages=389–422|year=1982|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?1982ApJ...257..389T&data_type=PDF_HIGH&whole_paper=YES&type=PRINTER&filetype=.pdf|accessdate=27 April 2015 |bibcode = 1982ApJ...257..389T |doi = 10.1086/159999 }}{{cite web|title=Galaxies, Clusters, and Superclusters|publisher=NOVA Online|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/universe/tour_ggs.html|accessdate=27 April 2015}} |- |[[Laniakea Supercluster|Laniakea]] || 160 Mpc || A group connected with the [[supercluster]]s of which the Local Group is a part.
Comprises roughly 300 to 500 [[galaxy groups and clusters]], centred on the [[Great Attractor]] in the [[Hydra-Centaurus Supercluster]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite news |work= National to the Milky Way }}{{cite web |work= Reuters |publisher= ScienceDaily |date= 3 September 2014 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/03/us-space-galaxies-idUSKBN0GY2C820140903|author= Klotz, |url=http://www.nature.com/news/earth-s-new-address-solar-system-milky-way-laniakea-1.15819|title= Earth's new address: 'Solar System, Milky Way, Laniakea' |author= Gibney, Elizabeth |date= 3 September 2014 |doi= 10.1038/nature.2014.15819 }}{{cite news |url= http://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/laniakea-home-supercluster-09032014/ |title= Laniakea: Our Home Supercluster |author= universe]], arranged in millions of superclusters, [[galactic filament]]s, and [[void (astronomy)|voids]], creating a [[cosmic web|foam-like superstructure]]. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web | last = Mackie | first = Glen | date=1 February 2002 | url = http://astronomy.swin.edu.au/~gmackie/billions.html | title = To see the Universe in a Grain of Taranaki Sand | publisher = Swinburne and its Implications|arxiv=1607.03909|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=830|issue=2|pages=83|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/830/2/83|issn=1538-4357|bibcode=2016ApJ...830...83C}}{{Cite possibly infinite || Beyond the observable universe lie the unobservable regions [[Particle horizon|from which no light has reached the Earth yet]].
No information is available, as light is the fastest travelling medium of information.
However, [[uniformitarianism]] argues that the Universe is likely to contain more galaxies in the same foam-like superstructure. || style="text-align:center;" | {{cite journal |last1=Margalef-Bentabol |first1=Berta |last2=Margalef-Bentabol |first2=Juan |last3=Cepa |first3=Jordi |title=Evolution of the cosmological horizons in a universe with countably infinitely many state equations |journal=Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics |date=February 2013 |volume=2013 |series=015 |issue=2 |doi=10.1088/1475-7516/2013/02/015 |arxiv=1302.2186|bibcode = 2013JCAP...02..015M|pages=015}} |- |} ==See also== *[[Orders of magnitude (length)]] *''[[Cosmic View]]'' *''[[Cosmic Zoom]]'' *''[[Pale Blue Dot]]'' *[[Powers of Ten (film)|''Powers of Ten'' (film)]] *''[[Galaxy Song]]'' ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Earth's location}} {{Earth}} {{Orders of magnitude}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Earth's Location In The Universe}} [[Category:Earth|Location in the Universe]] [[Category:Physical universe]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Ludovic Hubler | image = | imagesize = | caption = Ludovic Hubler au Brésil [[2003]] | birth_name = | Npseudonym = | birth_date = 11 September 1977 | birth_place = [[Bar-le-Duc]], [[Meuse]] | nationality = {{flag|France}} {{Infobox person|child=yes | height = {{height|m=1.88}} }} |notableworks=Le Monde en stop |awards={{awd|[[Pierre Loti]]|2010}} }}
'''Ludovic Hubler''' is a French traveller, most famous for his 5-year tour of the world completed entirely by hitchhiking (car, boat, etc.). He wrote the travelbook Le Monde en stop, rewarded by the 2010 [[Pierre Loti]] award.
== Biography == ===Childhood=== Born on September 11, 1977, Ludovic Hubler is the son of Monique and Jacques Hubler and the brother of the consultant Eric Hubler and the photograph Marc Hubler. Passionate about football and geography, he grew up in Wasselonne and Obernai in the Alsace region in eastern France. In June 2002, he graduated from [[EM Strasbourg Business School]] with a Master of Science in Management.
===Tour of the world by hitchhiking=== At the end of his Master's program, believing that discovering the realities of the world was a valuable pre-requisite to entering the work world, Ludovic Hubler decided to start a tour of the world using hitchhiking as his only means of transportation.
This adventure, which he baptized his, "life Phd", lasted 5 years during 2003-2008. From "sail-boat hitchhiking" to cross the Atlantic and the Pacific, to "ice breaker hitchhiking" to reach Antarctica; from crossing the Sahara desert or visiting countries as notorious as Colombia and Afghanistan, Ludovic used his thumb in all kinds of improbable and difficult to imagine situations.
His encounters were as numerous as they were diverse. Among the most striking is his meeting with the [[14th Dalai Lama]], who received him in his hometown [[Dharamshala]] (India) in 2007 but so were some of the thousands of students in all corners of the world with whom he shared his story.
Totalling the 5 years, the 170,000 kilometers travelled, the 59 countries visited, the hundreds of lectures given and recalling gratitude for the help of over 1,300 drivers gives an idea of the richness of Ludovic's trip - an adventure that was shared on a daily basis with pediatric cancer patients at the [[Hôpital civil, Strasbourg|Hospital of Strasbourg]], back home in Strasbourg, France.
<gallery> Image:katagdalailama.jpg|The 14th Dalai Lama giving Ludovic a [[khata]] Image:confafghanistan.JPG|Sharing his journey in a school in Afghanistan </gallery>
[[Image:Tribalzoneafghanistan.JPG|thumb|Hitchhiking in the tribal zones of Pakistan near the Afghan border]]
===After the tour=== Ludovic Hubler now lives in Menton and works as Head of Programmes and Field Operations for [[Peace and Sport]], ''L'organisation pour la paix par le sport'' placed under the High Patronage of HSH Prince [[Albert II of Monaco]].
He continues to regularly give lectures sharing his journey and what he learned on the road. Ludovic Hubler is now married to Panamanian native Marisol Richards Espinosa, whom he met during the trip in September 2005, as he hitchhiked through Panama.
== Bibliography == *2009 : ''Le Monde en stop, 5 années à l'école de la vie'', éditions Géorama. 2010 [[Pierre Loti]] award, rewarding the best travel book of the year 2009.

{{Notability|Biographies|date=November 2009}}
[[File:Ng gencli foto.jpg|thumb|200px|Neslihan Gökdemir]] '''Neslihan Gökdemir''' (born 1970, [[Istanbul]]) founded the [[Energy]] Forum of [[Turkey]] in 2001 and has since been the Chairman. She has been developing and delivering projects to establish an infrastructure for the energy industry and build a sustainable future.
Together with the co-operation of the academia this project ensures a continuous production and flow of information to the government, in particular, and authorities in the public and private sector so as to enhance the Turkish energy industry’s strategic position in the changing juncture across the world and in Turkey.
Upon graduation, Neslihan Gökdemir worked as an economic journalist and columnist. She also worked as a consultant for the construction and energy industries as well as for matters concerning [[Russia]] and the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] countries. She has attended many international conferences in these areas since 1992. She has worked as a journalist for economy, international relations and energy.
Neslihan Gökdemir graduated from the Department of Economics at [[Marmara University]]. During her undergraduate studies she attended [[Exeter University]] as an exchange student.
Neslihan Gökdemir is the Founder and Chairman of the Energy Forum of Turkey (2001), the Founder of the [[Energy market]] Monitoring and [[Evaluation|Rating]] Agency (2005) and, the Founder and Chairman of the Association of Energy [[Journalists]] (2007).
Neslihan Gökdemir is married. She speaks English and Russian.
==References== * [http://www.enerjiforumu.com] The National Energy Forum of Turkey * [http://www.greekembassy.org/embassy/Content/en/Article.aspx?office=1&folder=19&article=24088] Hellenic Republic Embassy of Greece * [http://www.tisk.org.tr/isveren_sayfa.asp?yazi_id=2147&id=102] Turkish Confederation of Employer Associations * [http://www.referansgazetesi.com/haber.aspx?HBR_KOD=27809&KTG_KOD=334] Referans News * [http://www.voanews.com/turkish/archive/2005-10/2005-10-28-voa7.cfm?moddate=2005-10-28] VOA News * [http://www.milliyet.com.tr/default.aspx?aType=SonDakika&ArticleID=987290] Milliyet News

A '''non-neutral plasma''' is a [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] for which the total charge is sufficiently different from zero, so that the electric field created by the un-neutralized charge plays an important or even dominant role in the plasma dynamics.<ref name="Davidson">R. C. Davidson, "Physics of Non-neutral Plasmas", (Addison-Wesley, Redwood City, CA, 1990)</ref> The simplest non-neutral plasmas are plasmas consisting of a single charge species. Examples of single species non-neutral plasmas that have been created in laboratory experiments are [http://nnp.ucsd.edu/ev.html plasmas consisting entirely of electrons],<ref>J. H. Malmberg and J. S. DeGrassie, Properties of a Non-neutral Plasma, Phys. Rev. Lett. 35, 577 (1975)</ref> [https://www.nist.gov/pml/div688/grp10/penning-traps.cfm pure ion plasmas],<ref>J. J. Bollinger and D. J. Wineland, Strongly Coupled Non-neutral Ion Plasma, Phys. Rev. Lett. 53, 348 (1984)</ref> [http://positrons.ucsd.edu/ positron plasmas],<ref>R. G. Greaves, M. D. Tinkle, and C. M. Surko, "Creation and uses of positron plasmas", Physics of Plasmas 1 (1994)</ref> and antiproton plasmas.<ref>G. B. Andresen et al., "Evaporative Cooling of Trapped Antiprotons to Cryogenic Temperatures", Phys. Rev. Lett. 105, 013003 (2010).</ref>
Non-neutral plasmas are used for research into basic plasma phenomena such as cross-magnetic field transport,<ref>F. Anderegg, "Internal Transport in Non-Neutral Plasmas," presented at Winter School on Physics with Trapped Charged Particles; to appear, Imperial College Press (2013) http://nnp.ucsd.edu/pdf_files/Anderegg_transport_leshouches_2012.pdf</ref> nonlinear vortex interactions,<ref>D. Durkin and J. Fajans, "Experiments on Two-Dimensional Vortex Patterns", Phys. Fluids, 12:289, 2000</ref> and [[plasma wave]]s and [[Plasma instability|instabilities]].<ref>F. Anderegg, C.F. Driscoll, D.H.E. Dubin, and T.M. O'Neil "Wave-Particle Interactions in Electron Acoustic Waves in Pure Ion Plasmas," Phys. Rev. Lett. 102, 095001 (2009)</ref> They have also been used to create cold neutral [[Anti-hydrogen|antimatter]], by carefully mixing and recombining cryogenic pure positron and pure antiproton plasmas. Positron plasmas are also used in [http://positrons.ucsd.edu/positron/atomicframe.html atomic physics experiments] that study the interaction of antimatter with neutral atoms and molecules. Cryogenic pure ion plasmas have been used in studies of [[Non-neutral plasmas#Cryogenic non-neutral plasmas: correlated states|strongly coupled plasmas]] <ref name = "Tan"/> and [https://arxiv.org/abs/1204.5789 quantum entanglement]. More prosaically, pure electron plasmas are used to produce the microwaves in microwave ovens, via the [[Cavity magnetron|magnetron instability]].
Neutral plasmas in contact with a solid surface (that is, most laboratory plasmas) are typically non-neutral in their edge regions. Due to unequal loss rates to the surface for electrons and ions, an electric field (the [[Ambipolar diffusion|"ambipolar field"]] ) builds up, acting to hold back the more mobile species until the loss rates are the same. The electrostatic potential (as measured in electron-volts) required to produce this electric field depends on many variables but is often on the order of the electron temperature.
Non-neutral plasmas for which all species have the same sign of charge have [[Non-neutral plasmas#Equilibrium of a single species non-neutral plasma|exceptional confinement properties]] compared to neutral plasmas. They can be confined in a [[thermal equilibrium]] state using only static electric and magnetic fields, in a [[Penning trap]] configuration (see Fig. 1).<ref name = "Dubin">Daniel H. E. Dubin and T. M. O’Neil, “Trapped Non-neutral Plasmas, Liquids and Crystals (the thermal equilibrium states), Rev. Mod. Phys. 71, 87 (1999)</ref> Confinement times of up to several hours have been achieved.<ref>J. H. Malmberg et al., "The Cryogenic Pure Electron Plasma", Proceedings of the 1984 Sendai Symposium on Plasma Nonlinear Phenomena" http://nnp.ucsd.edu/pdf_files/Proc_84_Sendai_1X.pdf</ref> Using the [[Non-neutral plasmas#Plasma loss processes.3B the rotating wall method|"rotating wall" method]],<ref name="Huang">X.-P. Huang, F. Anderegg, E.M. Hollmann, C.F. Driscoll and T.M. O'Neil "Steady-State Confinement of Non-neutral Plasma by Rotating Electric Fields,"Phys. Rev. Lett. 78, 875 (1997)</ref> the plasma confinement time can be increased arbitrarily.
Such non-neutral plasmas can also access novel states of matter. For instance, they can be cooled to cryogenic temperatures without [[Recombination (physics)|recombination]] (since there is no oppositely charged species with which to recombine). If the temperature is sufficiently low (typically on the order of 10 mK), the plasma can become a [[Non-neutral plasmas#Cryogenic non-neutral plasmas: correlated states|non-neutral liquid or a crystal]].<ref>J. H. Malmberg and T. M. O’Neil, “The pure electron plasma, liquid and crystal, Phys. Rev. Lett. 39, 1333 (1977)</ref> The [[Crystal structure|body-centered-cubic]] structure of these plasma crystals has been observed by [[Bragg scattering]] in experiments on [[Laser cooling|laser-cooled]] pure beryllium plasmas.<ref name = "Tan">J. N. Tan et al., "Observation of Long-Range Order in Trapped Ion Plasmas by Bragg Scattering", Phys. Rev. Lett. 75, 4198 (1995)</ref>
[[File:Penning Trap.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Diagram of a nonneutral plasma in a Penning trap.| Fig. 1. Diagram of a non-neutral plasma confined in a Penning trap.]]
==Equilibrium of a single species non-neutral plasma ==
Non-neutral plasmas with a single sign of charge can be confined for long periods of time using only static electric and magnetic fields. One such configuration is called a [[Penning trap]], after the inventor [[Frans Michel Penning|F. M. Penning]]. The cylindrical version of the trap is also sometimes referred to as a Penning-Malmberg trap, after Prof. John Malmberg. The trap consists of several cylindrically symmetric electrodes and a uniform magnetic field applied along the axis of the trap (Fig 1). Plasmas are confined in the axial direction by biasing the end electrodes so as to create an axial potential well that will trap charges of a given sign (the sign is assumed to be positive in the figure). In the radial direction, confinement is provided by the {{nowrap|v × B}} [[Lorentz force]] due to rotation of the plasma about the trap axis. Plasma rotation causes an inward directed Lorentz force that just balances the outward directed forces caused by the unneutralized plasma as well as the centrifugal force. Mathematically, radial force balance implies a balance between electric, magnetic and centrifugal forces:<ref name="Davidson"/>
{{NumBlk|:|<math> 0= q E_r +q v_\theta B + m {v_\theta}^2/r ,</math>|{{EquationRef|1}}}}
where particles are assumed to have mass ''m'' and charge ''q'', ''r'' is radial distance from the trap axis and ''E<sub>r</sub>'' is the radial component of the electric field. This quadratic equation can be solved for the rotational velocity <math> v_\theta</math>, leading to two solutions, a slow-rotation and a fast-rotation solution. The rate of rotation <math>\omega = -v_\theta/r</math> for these two solutions can be written as
:<math> \omega = \frac{\Omega_c}{2} \pm\sqrt{{\Omega_c}^2/4-q E_r/{m r}} </math>,
where <math>\Omega_c = q B/m</math> is the [[cyclotron frequency]]. Depending on the radial electric field, the solutions for the rotation rate fall in the range <math> 0 \le \omega/\Omega_c \le 1 </math>. The slow and fast rotation modes meet when the electric field is such that <math> q E_r/{m r} = {\Omega_c}^2/4 </math>. This is called the Brillouin limit; it is an equation for the maximum possible radial electric field that allows plasma confinement.
This radial electric field can be related to the plasma density ''n'' through the [[Poisson equation]],
:<math> \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r E_r)= qn/\epsilon_0 , </math>
and this equation can be used to obtain a relation between the density and the plasma rotation rate. If we assume that the rotation rate is uniform in radius (i.e. the plasma rotates as a rigid body), then Eq. (1) implies that the radial electric field is proportional to radius ''r''. Solving for ''E<sub>r</sub>'' from this equation in terms of <math>\omega</math> and substituting the result into Poisson's equation yields
{{NumBlk|:|<math> n=\frac{2\epsilon_0 m\omega(\Omega_c-\omega)}{q^2}. </math>|{{EquationRef|2}}}}
This equation implies that the maximum possible density occurs at the Brillouin limit, and has the value
:<math> n_B= \frac{\epsilon_0 m {\Omega_c}^2}{2 q^2}=\frac{B^2/(2 \mu_0)}{m c^2}</math>
where <math> c=1/\sqrt{\mu_0 \epsilon_0}</math> is the speed of light. Thus, the rest energy density of the plasma, n·m·c<sup>2</sup>, is less than or equal to the magnetic energy density <math> B^2/(2\mu_0)</math> of the magnetic field. This is a fairly stringent requirement on the density. For a magnetic field of 10 tesla, the Brillouin density for electrons is only n<sub>B</sub> = {{val|4.8|e=14|u=cm<sup>−3</sup>}}.
The density predicted by Eq.(2), scaled by the Brillouin density, is shown as a function of rotation rate in Fig. (2). Two rotation rates yield the same density, corresponding to the slow and fast rotation solutions. [[File:plasma density.jpg|thumb|right|alt=plasma density versus rotation rate.| Fig. 2. Density versus rotation rate for a single species plasma confined in a Penning trap.]]
=== Plasma loss processes; the rotating wall method ===
In experiments on single species plasmas, plasma rotation rates in the tens of kHz range are not uncommon, even in the slow rotation mode. This rapid rotation is necessary to provide the confining radial Lorentz force for the plasma. However, if there is neutral gas in the trap, collisions between the plasma and the gas cause the plasma rotation to slow, leading to radial expansion of the plasma until it comes in contact with the surrounding electrodes and is lost. This loss process can be alleviated by operating the trap in an ultra high vacuum. However, even under such conditions the plasma rotation can still be slowed through the interaction of the plasma with "errors" in the external confinement fields. If these fields are not perfectly cylindrically symmetric, the asymmetries can torque on the plasma, reducing the rotation rate. Such field errors are unavoidable in any actual experiment, and limit the plasma confinement time.<ref>J. H. Malmberg and C.F. Driscoll, "Long-Time Containment of a Pure Electron Plasma", Phys. Rev. Lett. 44, 654 (1980)</ref>
It is possible to overcome this plasma loss mechanism by applying a rotating field error to the plasma. If the error rotates faster than the plasma, it acts to spin up the plasma (similar to how the spinning blade of a blender causes the food to spin), counteracting the effect of field errors that are stationary in the frame of the laboratory. This rotating field error is referred to as a "rotating wall", after the theory idea that one could reverse the effect of a trap asymmetry by simply rotating the entire trap at the plasma rotation frequency. Since this is impractical, one instead rotates the trap electric field rather than the entire trap, by applying suitably phased voltages to a set of electrodes surrounding the plasma.<ref name="Huang"/>
==Cryogenic non-neutral plasmas: correlated states ==
When a non-neutral plasma is cooled to cryogenic temperatures, it does not recombine to a neutral gas as would a neutral plasma, because there are no oppositely charged particles with which to recombine. As a result, the system can access novel strongly coupled non-neutral states of matter, including plasma crystals consisting solely of a single charge species. These strongly coupled non-neutral plasmas are parametrized by the coupling parameter Γ, defined as
:<math>\Gamma = \frac{q^2}{4 \pi\epsilon_0 k_B T a},</math>
where <math> T</math> is the temperature and <math>a</math> is the [[Wigner-Seitz radius]] (or mean inter-particle spacing), given in terms of the density <math>n</math> by the expression <math> 4\pi a^3 n/3 =1</math>. The coupling parameter can be thought of as the ratio of the mean interaction energy between nearest-neighbor pairs, <math> q^2/(4\pi\epsilon_0 a)</math>, and the mean kinetic energy of order <math> k_b T</math>. When this ratio is small, interactions are weak and the plasma is nearly an ideal gas of charges moving in the mean-field produced by the other charges. However, when <math>\Gamma > 1</math> interactions between particles are important and the plasma behaves more like a liquid, or even a crystal if <math> \Gamma</math> is sufficiently large. In fact, computer simulations and theory have predicted that for an infinite homogeneous plasma the system exhibits a gradual onset of short-range order consistent with a liquid-like state for <math>\Gamma \approx 2 </math>, and there is predicted to be a first-order phase transition to a body-centered-cubic crystal for <math>\Gamma\simeq 175</math>.<ref name = "Dubin"/>
Experiments have observed this crystalline state in a pure beryllium ion plasma that was laser-cooled to the millikelvin temperature range. The mean inter-particle spacing in this pure ion crystal was on the order of 10-20 [[µm]], much larger than in neutral crystalline matter. This spacing corresponds to a density on the order of 10<sup>8</sup>-10<sup>9</sup> cm<sup>−3</sup>, somewhat less than the Brillouin limit for beryllium in the 4.5 tesla magnetic field of the experiment. Cryogenic temperatures were then required in order to obtain a <math> \Gamma</math> value in the strongly coupled regime. The experiments measured the crystal structure by the [[Bragg scattering|Bragg-scattering]] technique, wherein a collimated laser beam was scattered off of the crystal, displaying Bragg peaks at the expected scattering angles for a bcc lattice (See Fig. 3).<ref name="Tan"/>
When small numbers of ions are laser-cooled, they form crystalline "Coulomb clusters". The symmetry of the cluster depends on the form of the external confinement fields. An interactive 3D view of some of the clusters can be found [http://physics.ucsd.edu/~dhdpla/example.html here].
[[File:Bragg scattered light.jpg|thumb|right|alt=image of bragg scattered light.| Fig. 3. False color image of UV laser light that has undergone Bragg scattering off of a pure ion crystal.]]
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Plasma physics]]

The '''Nuclear Safety Research Reactor''' (NSRR) is a [[TRIGA]] design nuclear [[research reactor]] operated by the [[Japan Atomic Energy Agency]].
*First criticality: June 1975
As of 2006, the reactor has performed 3033 pulses and 1280 [[Nuclear fuel]] experiments. In 1989 the reactor underwent a power uprate.

'''Pipe flow''', a branch of [[hydraulics]] and [[fluid mechanics]], is a type of [[liquid]] flow within a closed [[Conduit (fluid conveyance)|conduit]] (conduit in the sense of a means of containment). The other type of flow within a conduit is [[open channel flow]]. These two types of flow are similar in many ways, but differ in one important aspect. Pipe flow does not have a [[free surface]] which is found in open-channel flow. Pipe flow, being confined within closed conduit, does not exert direct atmospheric pressure, but does exert hydraulic pressure on the conduit.
Not all flow within a closed conduit is considered pipe flow. [[Storm sewer]]s are closed conduits but usually maintain a free surface and therefore are considered open-channel flow. The exception to this is when a storm sewer operates at full capacity, and then can become pipe flow.
Energy in pipe flow is expressed as [[Hydraulic head|head]] and is defined by the [[Bernoulli's principle|Bernoulli equation]]. In order to conceptualize head along the course of flow within a pipe, diagrams often contain a hydraulic grade line. Pipe flow is subject to frictional losses as defined by the [[Darcy–Weisbach equation|Darcy-Weisbach formula]].
==States of flow== The behavior of pipe flow is governed mainly by the effects of [[viscosity]] and gravity relative to the [[inertia]]l forces of the flow. Depending on the effect of viscosity relative to inertia, as represented by the [[Reynolds number]], the flow can be either [[laminar flow|laminar]] or [[turbulent flow|turbulent]]. At a [[Reynolds number]] below the critical value of approximately 2040<ref name=Recrit>{{cite journal|last=Avila|first=K.|author2=D. Moxey |author3=A. de Lozar |author4=M. Avila |author5=D. Barkley|author5-link=Dwight Barkley |author6=B. Hof |title=The Onset of Turbulence in Pipe Flow|journal=Science|date=July 2011|volume=333|issue=6039|pages=192–196|doi=10.1126/science.1203223|pmid=21737736|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/333/6039/192|bibcode = 2011Sci...333..192A }}</ref> pipe flow will ultimately be laminar, whereas above the critical value turbulent flow can persist. In addition, the transition between laminar flow and turbulence can be sensitive to disturbance levels and imperfections.
Flow through pipes can roughly be divided into two: *[[Laminar flow]] - see [[Hagen-Poiseuille flow]] *[[Turbulent flow]] - see [[Moody diagram]]
==See also==
Mathematical equations and concepts :[[Bernoulli's principle|Bernoulli equation]] :[[Darcy–Weisbach equation]] Fields of study :[[Hydraulics]] :[[Fluid Mechanics]] Types of fluid flow :[[Open channel flow]] Fluid properties :[[Viscosity]] Fluid phenomena :[[Hydraulic head|Head]]
==References== <references />
==Further reading== *Chow, V. T. (1959/2008). ''Open-Channel Hydraulics''. Caldwell, New Jersey: Blackburn Press. {{ISBN|9780070859067}}.
[[Category:Fluid dynamics]] [[Category:Fluid mechanics]] [[Category:Piping]]

'''Platinum silicide''', also known as platinum monosilicide, is the inorganic compound with the formula PtSi and forms an orthorhombic crystalline structure when synthesized.
{| class="wikitable" |- | Chemical Formula | PtSi |- | Molecular Weight | 223.17 g/mol |- | CAS # | 12137-83-6 |- | Shape | Orthorhombic crystals |- | Electrical Resistivity | 25-35 μΩ cm<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.azom.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=8449 |title=AZO Materials - Platinum Silicide (PtSi) Semiconductors |publisher=azom.com |accessdate=2015-01-22 }}</ref> |- | Density | 12.4 g/cm³ |- | Melting Point | 1229 °C |}
==Structure and Bonding== The crystal structure of PtSi is orthorhombic, with each silicon atom having six neighboring platinum atoms. The distances between the silicon and the platinum neighbors are as follows: one at a distance of 2.41 angstroms, two at a distance of 2.43 angstroms, one at a distance of 2.52 angstroms, and the final two at a distance of 2.64 angstroms. Each platinum atom has six silicon neighbors at the same distances, as well as two platinum neighbors, at a distance of 2.87 and 2.90 angstroms. All of the distances over 2.50 angstroms are considered too far to really be involved in bonding interactions of the compound. As a result, it has been shown that two sets of covalent bonds compose the bonds forming the compound. One set is the three center Pt-Si-Pt bond, and the other set the two center Pt-Si bonds. Each silicon atom in the compound has one three center bond and two two center bonds. The thinnest film of PtSi would consist of two alternating planes of atoms, a single sheet of orthorhombic structures. Thicker layers are formed by stacking pairs of the alternating sheets. The mechanism of bonding between PtSi is more similar to that of pure silicon than pure platinum or Pt2Si, though experimentation has revealed metallic bonding character in PtSi that pure silicon lacks.<ref name="Kelp"> {{cite journal |last=Kelpeis |first=J.E. |last2=Beckstein |first2=O. |last3=Pankratoc |first3=O |last4= Hart |first4=G.L.W. |title=Chemical bonding, elasticity, and valence force field models: a case study for alpha-PtSi and PtSi |journal=The American Physical Society |year=2001 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.64.155110 |url=http://scholarsarchive.byu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1561&context=facpub }}</ref>
==Synthesis==
===Methods=== PtSi can be synthesized in several ways. The standard method involves depositing a thin film of pure platinum onto silicon wafers and heating in a conventional furnace at 450-600 °C for a half an hour in inert ambients. The process cannot be carried out in an oxygenated environment, as this results in the formation of an oxide layer on the silicon, preventing PtSi from forming.<ref name="Pant"> {{cite journal |last= Pant |first=A.K. |last2=Muraka |first2=S.P. |last3= Shepard |first3=C. |last4= Lanford |first4=W. |title=Kinetics of platinum silicide formation during rapid thermal processing |journal=Journal of Applied Physics |year=1992 |volume=72 |issue=5 |pages=1833–1836 |doi=10.1063/1.351654 }} </ref> A secondary technique for synthesis requires a [[Sputtering|sputtered]] platinum film deposited on a silicon substrate. Due to the ease with which PtSi can become contaminated by oxygen, several variations of the methods have been reported. Rapid thermal processing has been shown to increase the purity of PtSi layers formed.<ref name="Naem" > {{cite journal |last= Naem |first=A.A. |title=Platinum silicide formation using rapid thermal processing |journal=Journal of Applied Physics |year=1988 |volume=64 |issue=8 |pages=4161–4167 |doi=10.1063/1.341329 }}</ref> Lower temperatures (200-450 °C) were also found to be successful <ref name="Crider"> {{cite journal |last= Crider |first=C.A. |last2=Poate |first2=J.M. |last3= Rowe |first3=J.E. |last4= Sheng |first4=T.T. |title=Platinum silicide formation under vacuum and controlled impurity ambients |journal=Journal of Applied Physics |year=1981 |volume=52 |issue=4 |pages=2860–2868 |doi=10.1063/1.329018}}</ref> , higher temperatures produce thicker PtSi layers, though temperatures in excess of 950 °C formed PtSi with increased resistivity due to clusters of large PtSi grains.<ref name="AD"> {{cite journal |title=The properties of this platinum silicide films |journal=Platinum Metals Review |year=1976 |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=9 }}</ref>
===Kinetics=== Despite the synthesis method employed, PtSi forms in the same way. When pure platinum is first heated with silicon, Pt2Si is formed. Once all the available Pt and Si are used and the only available surfaces are Pt2Si, the silicide will begin the slower reaction of converting into PtSi. The activation energy for the Pt2Si reaction is around 1.38 eV, while it is 1.67 eV for PtSi.
Oxygen is extremely detrimental to the reaction, as it will bind preferably to Pt, limiting the sites available for Pt-Si bonding and preventing the silicide formation. A partial pressure of O<sub>2</sub> as low at 10<sup>−7</sup> has been found to be sufficient to slow the formation of the silicide. To avoid this issue inert ambients are used, as well as small annealing chambers to minimize amount of potential contamination.<ref name=Pant /> The cleanliness of the metal film is also extremely important, and unclean conditions result in poor PtSi synthesis.<ref name=Crider />
However, in certain cases an oxide layer can be beneficial. When PtSi is used as a [[Schottky barrier]], an oxide layer has been shown to be protective and prevent wear of the PtSi.<ref name=Pant />
==Applications== PtSi is a [[semiconductor]] and a Schottky barrier with high stability and good sensitivity, and can be used in infrared detection, thermal imaging, or ohmic and Schottyky contacts.<ref name="Azom">{{cite web |url=http://www.azom.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=8449 |title=Platinum Silicide (PtSi) Semiconductors |publisher=A to Z Materials}}</ref> Platinum silicide was most widely studied and used in the 1980s and 90’s, but has become less commonly used, due to its low quantum efficiency. PtSi is now most commonly used in infrared detectors, due to the large size of wavelengths it can be used to detect.<ref name="Del"> {{cite journal |last=Del Castillo |first=H.M. |last2=Gunapala |first2=S.D. |last3=Jones |first3=E.W. |last4= Lin |first4=T |title=Long wavelength PTSI infrared detectors and method of fabrication therof. |journal=US Patent |year=1997}}</ref> It has also been used in detectors for infrared astronomy. It can operate with good stability up to 0.05 °C. Platinum silicide offers high uniformity of arrays imaged. The low cost and stability makes it suited for preventative maintenance and scientific IR imaging.
==See also== * [[HgCdTe]] * [[Indium antimonide]] * [[Pt2Si]] * [[Silicon]] * [[Platinum]]
==External links== * [http://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/31918 /InfoScience]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Platinum]] [[Category:Semiconductor materials]] [[Category:Infrared sensor materials]] [[Category:Transition metal silicides]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2011}} [[Image:Karlsruhe Traction Current Converter Plant.JPG|thumb|A rotary converter plant in Germany where three phase AC of 50 hertz is transformed into single phase AC of 16.67 hertz for the traction current network]] [[File:B&O RR powerhouse.jpg|thumb|AC to DC plant in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], 1910]] A '''rotary converter plant''' is a facility at which [[rotary converter]]<nowiki/>s convert one form of electricity to another form of electricity. The installed combinations of motors and generators at a plant determine the possible type(s) of conversion. Such facilities also allow the setting of voltages and frequencies, if appropriate equipment is installed. Rotary converter plants were commonplace in [[railway electrification]] before the invention of [[mercury arc rectifier]]s in the 1920s.
At each facility, power from an AC power grid was converted to DC to feed into an [[overhead line]] or a [[third rail]] of a railway. Rotary converter plants were also used for coupling power grids of different frequencies and operation modes. The former [[Neuhof Substation]] was an example of the latter. Former machinery transmitters like the [[Alexanderson alternator]] were, strictly speaking, rotary converter plants.
In spite of modern power [[semiconductor]] technology, rotary converters are still common for feeding railway systems with AC of a different frequency from that of the main electricity grid. In Europe, this would typically be for [[15 kV AC railway electrification]].
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
== See also == * [[Traction current converter plant]] * [[Rotary converter]] * [[Motor–generator]] * [[Static inverter plant]] * [[Lyon-Moutiers DC transmission scheme]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rotary Converter Plant}} [[Category:Electric power conversion]] [[Category:Converter stations]]

[[Image:The Shabaka Stone.JPG|thumb|right|255px|Shabaka Stone on display in The [[British Museum]]. The stone measures {{convert|0.66|by|1.37|m}}.]] The '''Shabaka Stone''', sometimes Shabaqo, is a relic incised with an ancient Egyptian religious text, which dates from the [[Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt]].<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=111561&partId=1&searchText=shabako+stone&page=1 The Shabako Stone], British Museum</ref> In later years, the stone was likely used as a [[millstone]], which damaged the [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyphs]]. This damage is accompanied by other intentional defacements, leaving the hieroglyphic inscription in poor condition.
== Provenance ==
=== Historical origins === Originally erected as a lasting monument at the [[Memphis, Egypt#Great Temple of Ptah|Great Temple of Ptah in Memphis]] in the late eighth century BCE, the stone was at some point removed (for unknown reasons) to [[Alexandria]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=5|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> From there, it was transported by a navy vessel from Alexandria to England. It was brought back as ballast along with a capital of an Egyptian column, fragments of a Greco-Roman black basalt capital, two fragments of quartzite lintel of [[Senusret III|Senwosret III]], and a black granite kneeling statue of [[Ramesses II]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Proceedings of the Ninth International Congress of Egyptologists|last=El Hawary|first=Amr|publisher=Peeters Publishers & Department of Oriental Studies|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Goyon|editor-first=Jean-Claude|location=Leuven (Belgium)|pages=567–8|chapter=New Findings About the Memphite Theology|editor-last2=Cardin|editor-first2=Christine}}</ref> In 1805, the stone was donated to the [[British Museum]] by [[George Spencer, 2nd Earl Spencer]] (1758-1834), who was First Lord of the Admiralty and since 1794 the trustee of the museum.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Proceedings of the Ninth International Congress of Egyptologists|last=El Hawary|first=Amr|publisher=Peeters Publishers & Department of Oriental Studies|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Goyon|editor-first=Jean-Claude|location=Leuven (Belgium)|pages=567|chapter=New Findings About the Memphite Theology|editor-last2=Cardin|editor-first2=Christine}}</ref> In 1901, the stone was deciphered, translated, and interpreted for the first time by the American egyptologist, [[James Henry Breasted]].<ref name=":63">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=2|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> The monument has remained at the museum to the present day.<ref name=":5" />
=== Dating === Since this stone was meant to be a preservation of an older text, the question regarding the dating of the original work has been sought after. Attempts to attribute a definite date for the original text have been inconclusive. Breasted, [[Adolf Erman]], [[Kurt Sethe]], and [[Hermann Junker]] all dated the stone to the Old Kingdom.<ref name=":62" /> The stone is archaic, both linguistically (its language is similar to that used in the Pyramid Texts of the Old Kingdom) and politically (it alludes to the importance of Memphis as the first royal city).<ref name=":62" /> As such, [[Henri Frankfort]], John Wilson, [[Miriam Lichtheim]], and Erik Iverson have also assessed the stone to be from the Old Kingdom.<ref name=":62" /> However, Friedrich Junge and most other scholars since then have argued that the monument was produced in the [[Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt|Twenty-fifth Dynasty]].<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=10|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> Today, scholars feel it is clear that it cannot predate the [[Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt|Nineteenth Dynasty]].<ref>Van De Mierroop, Marc (2011). A history of Ancient Egypt. Massachusetts: Blackwell Publishing. p. 303. {{ISBN|978-1-4051-6070-4}}</ref>
== Composition ==
The stela is around {{convert|137|cm}} wide, with the left side height estimated at {{convert|91|cm}} and the right side about {{convert|95|cm}}.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=7|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> The written surface is {{convert|132|cm}} in width and on average, {{convert|66|cm}} in height.<ref name=":0" /> The rectangular hole in the center is {{convert|12|by|14|cm}}, with eleven radiating lines ranging in length from {{convert|25|to|38|cm}}.<ref name=":0" /> The area of the surface which has been completely worn-out measures {{convert|78|cm}} across.<ref name=":0" />
In 1901, James Henry Breasted identified the stone as a rectangular slab of black [[granite]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Breasted|first=James Henry|date=1901|title=The Philosophy of a Memphite Priest|url=|journal=Zeitschrift für ägyptische Sprache und Altertumskunde|volume=39|pages=458|via=}}</ref> While other scholars postulated that the monument was a slab or [[basalt]] or a conglomerate stone, a recent analysis by a scientist of the British Museum revealed the stone to be green [[breccia]] originating from [[Wadi Hammamat]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=6|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref>
== Content == The text includes two main divisions with a short introduction and an ending summary. The first division relates the unification of [[Upper and Lower Egypt]]. Ptah works through [[Horus]] to accomplish this unification. The other is a creation story, the '''Memphite Theology''', that establishes Ptah as the creator of all things, including gods.
The text stresses that it is in Memphis that the unification of Egypt took place.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Finnestad|first=Ragnhild Bjerre|date=1976|title=Ptah, Creator of the Gods: Reconsideration of the Ptah Sections of the Denkmai|url=|journal=Numen|volume=23|issue=2|pages=81|via=}}</ref> The inscription also states that this town was the burial-place of [[Osiris]], after he drifted ashore.<ref name=":10" />
=== Introduction and Titulary of the King === The first line of the stone presents the fivefold [[Ancient Egyptian royal titulary|royal titulary]] of the king: "The living Horus: Who prospers the Two Lands; the Two Ladies: Who prospers the Two Lands; the King of Upper and Lower Egypt: Neferkare; the Son of Re: [Shabaka], beloved of Ptah-South-of-His-Wall, who lives like Re forever.”<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=8|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> The first three names emphasize the king's manifestation as a living god (especially of the falcon-headed Horus, patron god to the Egyptian kings), while the latter two names (the king's throne name and birth name) refer to Egypt's division and unification.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=9|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref>
The second line, a dedicatory introduction, claims that the stone is a copy of the surviving contents of a worm-ridden, decaying [[papyrus]] found by the pharaoh [[Shabaka]] as he was inspecting the Great Temple of Ptah.<ref name=":2" />
=== The Unification of Egypt === Lines 3 to 47 describe the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt under the god Horus at Memphis.<ref name=":1" /> The text first declares the political and theological supremacy of the Memphite god Ptah, the king of both Upper and Lower Egypt, and the creator of the [[Ennead]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=13|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> The inscription then describes how Horus, as a manifestation of Ptah, initially rules [[Lower Egypt]] while his rival Set rules [[Upper Egypt]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=14|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> However, Horus receives Upper Egypt from [[Geb]], becoming the sole ruler of the land.<ref name=":3" />
=== The Memphite Theology === Lines 48 to 64 recount the creation myth known as the Memphite Theology.<ref name=":1" /> [[Ptah]], the patron god of craftsmen, metalworkers, artisans, and architects was viewed as a creator-god, a divine craftsman of the universe who was responsible for all existence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=17|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> Creation was first a spiritual and intellectual activity, facilitated by the divine heart (thought) and tongue (speech/word) of Ptah.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Bodine|first=Joshua J.|date=April 2009|title=The Shabaka Stone: An Introduction|url=|journal=Studia Antiqua|volume=7|issue=1|pages=18–9|via=BYU ScholarsArchive}}</ref> Then, creation became a physical activity carried out by [[Atum]], who, created by Ptah's teeth and lips, produced the Ennead from his seed and hands.<ref name=":4" />
=== Summary === Lines 61 through 64 summarize the text as a whole.<ref name=":1" />
== Purpose == According to Ragnhild Bjerre Finnestad, there are three theories on the possible purpose of the Shabaka text: # To assert the supremacy of the Memphite theological system over the Heliopolitan # To claim the hegemony of the Memphis and its priesthood over Heliopolis and its priesthood # To present an ontology.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Finnestad|first=Ragnhild Bjerre|date=1976|title=Ptah, Creator of the Gods: Reconsideration of the Ptah Sections of the Denkmai|url=|journal=Numen|volume=23|issue=2|pages=82–3|via=}}</ref> As a temple text written down and set up in the temple of Ptah, it is likely that the Shabaka Stone served a religious, cultic-theological purpose, placing its subject matter within a cultic frame of reference.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Finnestad|first=Ragnhild Bjerre|date=1976|title=Ptah, Creator of the Gods: Reconsideration of the Ptah Section of the Denkmai|url=|journal=Numen|volume=23|issue=2|pages=83|via=}}</ref>
== Damage == Projecting from the rectangular hole in the center of the stone are radial rough stripes, which destroyed the inscription within a radius of 78 cm, measured from the middle of the stone.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Proceedings of the Ninth International Congress of Egyptologists|last=El Hawary|first=Amr|publisher=Peeters Publishers & Department of Oriental Studies|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Goyon|editor-first=Jean-Claude|location=Leuven (Belgium)|pages=569|chapter=New Findings About the Memphite Theology|editor-last2=Cardin|editor-first2=Christine}}</ref> According to the secondary literature on the monument, this damage occurred because the stone was re-used as a millstone.<ref name=":6" /> The oldest reference speculating the stone's use as a millstone is found in the display of the British Museum of 1821.<ref name=":6" /> However, the stone could instead have been the foundation of something round, possibly a column or a pillar.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=Proceedings of the Ninth International Congress of Egyptologists|last=El Hawary|first=Amr|publisher=Peeters Publishers & Department of Oriental Studies|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Goyon|editor-first=Jean-Claude|location=Leuven (Belgium)|pages=570|chapter=New Findings About the Memphite Theology|editor-last2=Cardin|editor-first2=Christine}}</ref>
Some parts of the stone were intentionally cut out during the Dynastic Period.<ref name=":7" /> This included the name of Seth (line 7), a god which was condemned during this time.<ref name=":7" /> Additionally, [[Psamtik II]] or [[Psamtik III]] erased the proper name and throne name of Shabaka from the stone.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=Proceedings of the Ninth International Congress of Egyptologists|last=El Hawary|first=Amr|publisher=Peeters Publishers & Department of Oriental Studies|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Goyon|editor-first=Jean-Claude|location=Leuven (Belgium)|pages=571|chapter=New Findings About the Memphite Theology|editor-last2=Cardin|editor-first2=Christine}}</ref> Psamtik III then engraved his name onto the stone, but his name was in turn erased by the Persians during their conquest.<ref name=":9">{{Cite book|title=Proceedings of the Ninth International Congress of Egyptologists|last=El Hawary|first=Amr|publisher=Peeters Publishers & Department of Oriental Studies|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Goyon|editor-first=Jean-Claude|location=Leuven (Belgium)|pages=572|chapter=New Findings About the Memphite Theology|editor-last2=Cardin|editor-first2=Christine}}</ref>

A '''soft-switching three-level inverter''' (S3L inverter) is a high-efficiency [[power electronics|power electronic]] [[inverter]] intended, in particular, for use with [[three-phase drives]], as a [[grid-tie inverter]] for [[photovoltaic]] installations or [[wind turbines]] and in [[power supplies]]. The topology was developed in 2009 at [[HTWG Konstanz]] (Constance University of Applied Sciences).
== Operating principle ==
[[File:S3L-Inverter Prinzipschaltbild.png|thumb|Schematic circuit diagram of the S3L inverter. The snubber circuit is highlighted in grey.]]
Inverters are used for converting [[DC voltage]] into [[AC voltage]]. Their construction typically makes use of [[power transistor]]s and [[diode]]s. These are operated as electronic switches. In conventional designs using "hard" switching, this gives rise to switching losses<ref name="Peter R. W. Martin (editor)">Peter R. W. Martin (editor): Applikationshandbuch IGBT- und MOSFET-Leistungsmodule. ISLE Verlag, 1998, {{ISBN|3-932633-24-5}}, Section 1.2.3 Qualitatives Schaltverhalten von MOSFET und IGBT beim harten Schalten (PDF version).</ref> which, especially for high values of the [[switching frequency]], cause a reduction in their [[energy conversion efficiency]]. To improve their efficiency, high-power inverters (from about 10 kW) frequently make use of a technique referred to as a three-level design ([[three-level inverter]]).<ref name="Akira Nabae, Isao Takahashi, Hirofumi Akagi">Akira Nabae, Isao Takahashi, [[Hirofumi Akagi]]: A New Neutral-Point-Clamped PWM Inverter. In: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications. IA-17, No. 5, 1981, pp. 518–523, doi:10.1109/TIA.1981.4503992.</ref>
Forming the basis of the S3L inverter is a hard-switching three-level inverter of this kind with a T-type topology.<ref name="M. Schweizer, J. W. Kolar">M. Schweizer, J. W. Kolar: High efficiency drive system with 3-level T-type inverter. In: Proceedings of the 2011-14th European Conference on Power Electronics and Applications (EPE 2011). 2011, {{ISBN|9789075815153}}, pp. 1–10.</ref> This base design is supplemented by a snubber circuit consisting of a few passive components.<ref name="M. W. Gekeler">M. W. Gekeler: Soft switching three level inverter with passive snubber circuit (S3L inverter). In: Proceedings of the 2011-14th European Conference on Power Electronics and Applications (EPE 2011). 2011, {{ISBN|9789075815153}}, pp. 1–10.</ref> It prevents the occurrence of simultaneously high values of voltage and current, and hence high power dissipation values, during the switching process. All switching processes therefore take place in a "soft" manner. In this way switching losses are largely avoided. Furthermore, because the snubber circuit functions, in principle, without losses, the conversion efficiency of the inverter remains high even for high values of the switching frequency.<ref name="Manfred W. Gekeler">Manfred W. Gekeler: Weich schaltender 3-Stufen-Pulswechselrichter mit verlustfreiem Entlastungsnetzwerk. In: International ETG Congress 2011 (ETG Technical Report 130 Part B). 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-8007-3376-7}}, pp. 264-270.</ref><ref name="US Patent">3-Level Pulse Width Modulation Inverter with Snubber Circuit; US Patent No. US 8,462,524 B2; Date of Patent: Jun. 11, 2013; Inventor: Manfred W. Gekeler, Constance (DE); Assignee: Hochschule Konstanz, Constance (DE)</ref>
